docs.filename: Zenit Consult: Denmark's Premium IT Consultant Marketplace and Financial Sector Specialist.md
docs.content:
# Zenit Consult: Denmark's veteran IT consultant marketplace

**Zenit Consult A/S is a 27-year-old IT consulting placement firm managing 1,400+ hand-picked consultants** with deep roots in Denmark's financial sector and an estimated revenue of $269 million USD. Founded in 1997 and recently transitioning leadership from founder Michael Willumsen to new CEO Jan Hansen in 2024, the company operates as a premium consultant-matching intermediary emphasizing quality, long-term relationships, and comprehensive support systems. Their core value proposition centers on providing consultants who deliver superior outcomes through rigorous vetting, precise project matching, and ongoing quality assurance—claiming freelancers from Zenit add more value than identical consultants from competitors.

The company serves major Danish enterprises including **PensionDanmark (660,000+ members), Bluegarden (managing payroll for 750,000 Danes), TopDanmark, and BRF Kredit**, maintaining some client relationships since their founding year. With offices in Søborg and Aarhus, they operate exclusively in Denmark and participate in the UN Global Compact since 2019. Recent developments include a complete brand refresh with Sebastian Sejer & Co, leadership succession planning, and active expansion in cloud transformation (Azure), data architecture, and financial compliance technologies.

## The consultant marketplace model explained

Zenit Consult operates as an **IT consultant placement intermediary** rather than a traditional consultancy. They maintain a curated database of 1,400+ independent IT consultants across Denmark, matching them to client projects based on technical capabilities, industry knowledge, and cultural fit. The company employs approximately 40-50 core staff focused on sales, sourcing, operations, and administration while their consultant network executes actual client projects.

Their three-phase service delivery model begins with **clarification sessions** where they collaborate closely with clients to identify competency gaps and provide advisory services leveraging their 27 years of cross-industry experience. The **profile matching phase** draws from their extensively vetted consultant pool—each having undergone rigorous recruitment including technical assessments, behavioral evaluations, criminal background checks, and reference verification. The critical difference lies in their **follow-up commitment**: clients receive continuous quality assurance at fixed intervals throughout engagements, with regular evaluations ensuring satisfaction and performance tracking for future placements.

The business model generates revenue through hourly or project-based consultant placement fees, operating via both framework agreements (including SKI 02.06, 02.14, 02.17, and SKI 17.13 for public sector work) and direct contracts. While specific pricing remains undisclosed, they emphasize delivering "the right price" through transparent commercial negotiations. Their competitive positioning focuses on relationship quality over short-term market exploitation—multiple client testimonials specifically note Zenit "never abuses favorable market conditions" and aims for stability.

What distinguishes their approach is the **comprehensive consultant support infrastructure**. Unlike pure staffing agencies that simply place talent, Zenit provides continuous professional development, active sales work ensuring project flow, networking opportunities through regular events and workshops, and full backing during client engagements. This creates stronger consultant loyalty (68+ consultants have remained with them for over 12 years) which translates to better client outcomes through well-supported, motivated consultants.

## Complete service portfolio and technical capabilities

Zenit's services span five core categories covering all IT project phases. **Analysis & Design** encompasses system integration, solution architecture, cloud solutions, and infrastructure planning. **Project & Program Management** includes IPMA, Prince2, and MSP methodologies alongside agile frameworks with certified Scrum Masters, Product Owners, and Release Train Engineers. Their **Advisory & Leadership** practice covers enterprise architecture, change management, organizational development, agile coaching, and interim management roles.

On the technical side, **Implementation services** include DevOps, system development, ISTQB-certified testing, and technical installation/configuration. Their **Technical Services** specialty addresses system integration, database architecture, optimization/tuning, solution architecture, and security consulting.

The technology stack reveals expertise across **legacy and modern platforms**: .NET/C#, Java/J2EE, PL/1, Cobol, CICS for mainframe systems, DB/2 and Oracle databases, plus contemporary technologies including AWS and Azure cloud platforms, robotics/RPA, and modern application development frameworks. Recent 2024 job postings indicate heavy investment in **Azure cloud transformation**, Domain-Driven Design architecture, MSSQL database systems, Intune software deployment, and specialized areas like Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and machine learning applications.

Their consultant recruitment patterns show concentration in six key areas: **cloud architects** building Azure platforms for large organizations, **Java and C# developers** with modern frameworks, **data architects** specializing in data flow mapping and MSSQL, **application modernization specialists** handling package management and deployment, **Domain-Driven Design experts** facilitating workshops and technical coaching, and **financial compliance specialists** particularly in AML systems. This technology mix positions them strongly for organizations undergoing digital transformation, cloud migration, or regulatory compliance initiatives in the Danish market.

## Client relationships built on financial sector expertise

Zenit's client base concentrates heavily in Denmark's **financial services sector**—their origin market where founding leadership built core competencies. Major named clients include PensionDanmark (Denmark's largest labor market pension company), Bluegarden/Multidata (managing payroll for 20% of Scandinavian wage earners), TopDanmark, Købstædernes Forsikring, BRF Kredit, and insurance companies. Beyond financial services, they serve public sector organizations through SKI framework agreements, plus clients in energy, retail, academic, and unemployment insurance sectors.

The **PensionDanmark case study** demonstrates their capability at scale. For a major Azure cloud platform migration project, Zenit doubled consultant staffing for one year to compress a 2-year timeline, providing experienced consultants who understood financial governance and compliance requirements without lengthy onboarding. IT Director Peter Juncker emphasized their consultants come as "sensible and self-reliant people" who understand pension company regulations aren't surprising but expected.

Their **14-year partnership with Bluegarden** showcases relationship durability. COO Per Hviid described the collaboration as "professionally very strong and stable," noting Zenit consistently delivers the right consultants while maintaining pricing stability even during favorable market conditions. He specifically valued their flexibility and ability to deliver specific competencies on short notice—critical for a company affecting 750,000 Danish employees' monthly paychecks.

Recurring themes across client testimonials include **trust and transparency** ("never afraid that consultants will package things instead of being straightforward"), **industry-specific knowledge** (especially financial sector regulations and compliance), **honest communication without overselling**, and **consultant quality** backed by rigorous vetting. BRF Kredit's IT Manager Jens Christian Hansen noted their consultants' financial sector experience means "the consultant can go more directly to work without a long introduction to the industry"—a significant efficiency advantage in regulated environments.

The company maintains that their first customers from 1997-98 remain active clients today, demonstrating exceptional relationship longevity in a competitive market. This retention suggests genuine value delivery beyond initial sales promises.

## Competing in Denmark's $640M IT consulting market

The Danish IT consulting and implementation market reached **$640 million USD in 2024** and projects to $776.86 million by 2029 at a 4.04% CAGR. Denmark ranks 2nd in the EU for digital competitiveness with 85% of citizens actively using online services and fully digitalized government communications. The broader IT services market totals $12.16 billion, growing 5.26% annually. This highly digitized economy with tech-savvy populations creates strong demand for expert IT consultants, though Danish IT services typically cost 15-20% more than EU averages.

Zenit faces competition from **multiple tiers of firms**. Large international players include McKinsey, BCG, Bain, Accenture, Deloitte, IBM, Cognizant, TCS, and Infosys offering global resources and brand recognition. Nordic and Danish firms like Implement (ranked #6 in 2020 Graduateships), Novo Nordisk Consulting, Valcon, Twoday (~2,050 employees), Netcompany-Intrasoft, and Right People Group compete directly in the local market. Similar IT consulting houses include NETIP A/S, ENVO IT A/S, CGI, Hyperbolic, and ProData Consult (founded 1989).

Zenit's **competitive differentiation** rests on five pillars. First, their rigorous consultant selection maintaining "only the best of the best" through comprehensive recruitment evaluating technical skills and human qualities. Second, their matching precision leveraging 27 years of industry knowledge to align consultant capabilities with client needs and organizational culture. Third, their support philosophy claiming freelance consultants from Zenit deliver more value than identical consultants from competitors because of comprehensive backing. Fourth, their quality assurance process with immediate post-start follow-up and continuous evaluation. Fifth, their cultural values emphasizing transparency, honesty, and relationship longevity over short-term profit maximization.

Market trends affecting Zenit include **surging cloud migration demand** (their heavy Azure focus positions them well), increased cybersecurity emphasis, AI/ML integration requirements, cross-industry digital transformation, talent scarcity driving salary increases (IDA projects 7% engineering salary hikes in 2024), remote/hybrid work models, and growing ESG/sustainability expectations. Their 2019 UN Global Compact participation and dedicated Sustainability Manager address the latter trend. The company's description as "one of Denmark's largest consulting firms" and "leading IT consultancy" suggests mid-to-large player status, though exact market share remains undisclosed.

## Leadership transition marks new growth phase

After 27 years leading Zenit Consult, **founder Michael Willumsen stepped down as CEO in 2024** while remaining owner and director. New CEO **Jan Hansen** now leads the company's next growth phase. Willumsen's entrepreneurial background spans 28+ years across multiple ventures including director positions at Axel Invest ApS, TAMS HOLDING ApS, and board membership at MS Branding A/S.

The current C-suite features **Lisa Bindner as COO/Administrationsdirektør**, bringing legal education and expertise in sustainable solutions, conflict resolution, organizational development, and HR/personnel law. Her responsibilities span tender processes, GDPR compliance, CSR initiatives, and creating the organizational infrastructure. She's described as having "strong social competencies, empathy, and ability to build trust" with fluency in English and German. **Tina Hammerstrøm serves as CFO** managing financial operations and oversight.

The **sales organization** comprises four identified sales managers plus Karsten Petersen as Sales & Consulting Manager, indicating significant business development infrastructure. The **sourcing division** includes four senior sourcing managers and additional sourcing managers responsible for managing the 1,400+ consultant database and matching consultants to projects. Supporting functions include a Bid Manager, Office Manager Puk Wendler, Back Office Manager, Financial Controller, and notably a **Sustainability Manager**—a dedicated role demonstrating commitment to corporate responsibility.

Historical partners include **Bjarne Thorsen** (co-founder and partner from 1997-2022, no longer active) and previous executives whose roles have evolved during the 2024 leadership transition. The organizational structure maintains a lean core team of approximately 40-50 employees focused on sales, sourcing, operations, and administration, while the extended network of 1,400+ freelance consultants executes client projects.

Company culture emphasizes **"100% support for consultants"** as their foundational philosophy, claiming consultants perform better work when fully backed by their placement firm. Regular consultant meetings with sports activities, social gatherings, and professional development workshops foster community. Their UN Global Compact participation since October 17, 2019 (next Communication on Progress due July 31, 2025) plus support for Danske Hospitalsklovne (Danish Hospital Clowns) demonstrates corporate social responsibility. Consultant testimonials consistently emphasize transparency, honesty, strong matching, flexibility, and professional standards—with one noting Zenit is "not as 'puffed up' as other companies in the industry."

## Recent developments signal strategic evolution

The **2024 leadership transition** from founder Michael Willumsen to new CEO Jan Hansen represents the most significant organizational change in Zenit's 27-year history. This succession planning suggests maturation beyond founder-led operations while Willumsen retains ownership and directorship for continuity.

**Brand refresh and repositioning** occurred through partnership with Sebastian Sejer & Co design agency, developing new brand strategy and visual identity ahead of their relaunch. The professional redesign positions them as "one of Denmark's largest consulting firms" with updated communications across all channels. This investment in brand equity indicates ambitions for continued growth and market presence.

Social responsibility initiatives expanded in 2024 with a **10,000 DKK donation to Danmarks Indsamling** (part of 100+ million DKK total raised) and ongoing support for Danske Hospitalsklovne. Their UN Global Compact active participation continues with the next Communication on Progress due July 2025, maintaining accountability to the Ten Principles.

**Technology focus shifts toward cloud and modern architecture**. Throughout 2024, intensive recruitment targeted cloud architects for Azure platform development, Domain-Driven Design specialists, application modernization consultants, and financial compliance experts in AML/ML systems. Specific job postings in Copenhagen, Roskilde, Aarhus, Silkeborg, and the Triangle Region indicate geographic expansion of service delivery while maintaining Denmark-only focus. The heavy Azure emphasis aligns with broader market trends as enterprises accelerate cloud migration.

Company events maintained consultant community engagement. The **2024 Winter Party** at Teaterkælderen featured entertainment and networking, while other gatherings included discussions on AI and technology trends with industry leaders like IBM Denmark. These regular social and professional events reinforce their consultant support philosophy and create differentiation from pure transactional staffing firms.

## Contact information and physical presence

**Headquarters (Sjælland/Zealand):** Vandtårnsvej 77, 2860 Søborg, Denmark—located near Copenhagen providing access to the capital region's dense business ecosystem. Phone: +45 46 99 19 03. The office welcomes in-person visits with informal accessibility ("happy to give you a cup of coffee and a candy if you stop by").

**Aarhus Office (Jylland/Jutland):** Kannikegade 16 A, 3rd floor, DK-8000 Aarhus, Denmark—positioned in Denmark's second-largest city serving Central and Northern Jutland markets. Phone: +45 40 92 19 20.

A secondary address appears in business registries at **Dybendalsvænget 2, 2630 Taastrup**, which may be a previous location or administrative address. The recent move from Taastrup to Søborg suggests office consolidation or relocation strategy.

**Email contacts** include info@zenit.dk for general inquiries and client meetings, search@zenit.dk or blivkonsulent@zenit.dk for consultant recruitment, and individual @zenit.dk addresses for all staff members. The company maintains professional accessibility with direct phone numbers published for key personnel.

**Digital presence** centers on LinkedIn (5,060+ followers at dk.linkedin.com/company/zenit-consult) with regular postings of consultant opportunities, company updates, and industry engagement. Their Facebook page (facebook.com/zenitconsult) shows 199 likes with lower activity levels. The website www.zenit.dk underwent complete redesign with new visual identity, featuring client testimonials, case studies, service descriptions, and consultant recruitment information.

**Business registration:** CVR number 20515708, Aktieselskab (A/S) legal structure, share capital 500,000 DKK, NACE code 620200 (IT consulting services). The company operates exclusively within Denmark's borders with no international presence—a deliberate strategic choice focusing resources on deep Danish market knowledge.

## Strategic intelligence for digital consultants

**Market positioning opportunities:** Zenit's exclusive Denmark focus and financial sector concentration create potential partnership opportunities for international firms needing local market access or specialized consultants. Their 1,400+ consultant database provides rapid resource scaling for project peaks without long-term employment commitments.

**Technology alignment:** If your projects involve **Azure cloud migration, Domain-Driven Design implementation, MSSQL database systems, or financial compliance requirements** (particularly AML systems), Zenit's consultant pool aligns directly with these capabilities. Their recent heavy recruitment in these areas suggests both capability depth and client demand.

**Competitive intelligence:** Their emphasis on relationship quality over transactional efficiency means they're less price-competitive but more suitable for **complex, regulated environments requiring consultants who understand governance frameworks**. The 14-year Bluegarden partnership and decades-long client relationships indicate they excel in stable, long-term engagements rather than rapid staff augmentation.

**Procurement considerations:** For public sector work, Zenit holds **SKI framework agreements 02.06, 02.14, 02.17, and SKI 17.13**, streamlining procurement processes for government entities. This pre-qualification accelerates consultant sourcing for qualifying projects.

**Cultural fit assessment:** Client testimonials consistently emphasize **transparency, honest communication, and straightforward advice without overselling**. If your project culture values directness and expects consultants to integrate quickly without extensive hand-holding, Zenit's philosophy aligns well. Their consultants are described as "sensible and self-reliant" rather than requiring extensive support.

**Differentiation from competitors:** Unlike large international consultancies offering standardized methodologies and junior consultants, or pure staffing agencies providing bodies without support, Zenit occupies a middle ground—experienced independent consultants with institutional backing. This model works best when you need **senior-level expertise without the overhead of Big 4 firms** but want more quality assurance than direct freelancer sourcing.

**Risk considerations:** The 2024 leadership transition from founder to professional CEO introduces execution risk during the transition period. Their exclusive Denmark focus limits international project support. Reliance on independent consultants rather than employees may affect consistency, though their quality assurance processes aim to mitigate this. The private ownership and undisclosed financial details limit transparency compared to public competitors.

**Growth trajectory indicators:** Recent brand refresh, leadership succession, office relocation, and intensive recruitment in cloud/modern architecture suggest a company in **active growth phase transitioning from founder-led to professionally managed**. The estimated $269 million revenue with 40-50 core staff indicates strong revenue per employee, typical of consultant placement models with high-margin services.

## ðŸŽ¨ DESIGN GUIDELINES (Keep it simple!)

### Typography
- **Font**: Sans-serif (Helvetica, Arial, Oxygen, or modern Danish fonts)
- **Headers**: Bold, 44-56pt
- **Body**: Regular, 24-32pt
- **Never smaller than 20pt** (audience needs to read it)

### Color Scheme (Suggestions)
- **Primary**: Atlas Group colors (confirm what they are)
- **Accent**: One bright color (for highlights, checkmarks)
- **Background**: White or very light gray (not dark backgrounds)
- **Text**: Dark gray or black

### Spacing
- **Lots of white space** â€“ slides look crowded when full
- **Leave 20% of slide empty** minimum
- **Big margins** around text (not edge-to-edge)

### Images/Visuals
- **Use real photos** where possible (people, collaboration, work)
- **Avoid cheesy stock photos** ("people in business attire" generic shots)
- **Icons are good** for processes/flows
- **One visual per slide** maximum
- **Make visuals large** â€“ they should fill ~50% of slide

### Layout Pattern (For cases/stories)
```
[LARGE IMAGE - 50% of slide]

HEADLINE (Bold, punchy)
(Smaller descriptive text)

[OR]

HEADLINE (Top)
[IMAGE - centered, large]
Key points below (3-4 bullets max)
```

---

---

## ðŸŽ¬ PRESENTING TIPS

### Before the Meeting
- [ ] Practice once (time yourself)
- [ ] Know your numbers (time per case, actual results)
- [ ] Have backup answers ready
- [ ] Mute your phone
- [ ] Have handout copies (optional)

### During Presentation
- **Stand, don't sit** (more confident)
- **Look at audience, not screen**
- **Let slides be visual anchors** â€“ you do the talking
- **Pause after each case** â€“ let them ask questions
- **Go deep on what interests them** (be flexible with time)
- **Use the "Tell, Show, Tell" method**:
  1. Tell them what you're going to show
  2. Show the visual
  3. Tell them what it means

### Handling Objections
- Listen fully before answering
- Answer concisely
- Use an example from the cases
- Offer follow-up (vs. trying to convince in 60 seconds)

### Common Questions & Quick Answers

**Q: "How long is prototyping?"**
A: "3-6 weeks depends on scope. But the point is it's weeks not months, and you're testing with actual end-users."

**Q: "What if AI makes mistakes?"**
A: "That's why we call it Responsible AI â€“ it's a tool that people use, not a tool that replaces people. We catch errors together."

**Q: "How much does this cost?"**
A: "Depends on the project. The prototype cases cost between [X-Y]. Let's explore which model fits first â€“ pricing comes second."

---

That's the moment you know you've validated the idea. Then we moved into production."

# 6Degrees Recruiting OS - Project Context

## What This Is
Internal recruiting software MVP replacing expensive headhunter processes.
4-step funnel: Job Context → Shortlist → Deep Profile → Outreach

## Pricing Model
- 1 Credit = 4 DKK = ~€0.54
- Pilot: 20,000 DKK = 5,000 Credits
- Step 2: 93 credits (€50) | Step 3: 278 credits (€150) | Step 4: 463 credits (€250)

## Tech Stack
- Data: EnrichLayer API (LinkedIn enrichment)
- Frontend: Next.js + shadcn/ui
- Backend: NestJS + FastAPI
- DB: PostgreSQL + pgvector

## Compliance Requirements
- EU AI Act ready (Aug 2026 enforcement)
- GDPR compliant (decision support, not automated decisions)
- All outputs require human-in-the-loop
- No personality profiling – only "Career & Workstyle Indicators"

## Key Constraints
- NO "personality" language anywhere
- All scores must show evidence + confidence
- Share links required on all outputs
- Logging for audit trail (3-year retention)

## When I Ask About...
- **Pricing**: Reference Section 11 of spec
- **Algorithm**: Reference Section 12 (alignment score weights)
- **Compliance**: Reference Sections 13-14 (logging, GDPR)
- **UI**: Reference Section 15-16 (missing components, copy standards)
- **API**: Reference Section 19

**12. Alignment Score Algorithm**

**12.1 Overview**

The Alignment Score (0-100%) measures candidate-job fit based on
weighted, explainable factors. It is NOT a hire/no-hire
recommendation---it indicates relative alignment strength.

**12.2 Component Weights**

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Component**           **Weight**   **Description**
  ----------------------- ------------ -----------------------------------
  Hard Skills Match       35%          Required skills from job
                                       description

  Experience Relevance    25%          Years + domain match

  Industry Alignment      15%          Same/adjacent industry experience

  Seniority Fit           15%          Title level appropriate for role

  Location Match          10%          Geography compatibility
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

**12.3 Calculation Methodology**

**12.3.1 Hard Skills Match (35%)**

Uses ESCO taxonomy for skill normalization. Semantic similarity (cosine
similarity \> 0.85) for non-exact matches. Score = (exact_matches +
semantic_matches) / total_required_skills.

**12.3.2 Experience Relevance (25%)**

Penalizes both under and over-qualification. Sweet spot: 70-130% of
required years. Over-qualification (\>130%) receives slight penalty due
to flight risk.

**12.3.3 Industry Alignment (15%)**

Same industry: 100%. Adjacent industry (e.g., fintech → banking): 75%.
Unrelated: 30% (transferable skills baseline).

**12.3.4 Seniority Fit (15%)**

Exact match: 100%. One level senior: 85%. One level junior (stretch):
75%. Overqualified (\>1 level): 60%. Underqualified: 50%.

**12.3.5 Location Match (10%)**

Remote job: 100%. Same city: 100%. Same country + hybrid: 85%. Willing
to relocate: 70%. Same country only: 50%. International: 30%.

**12.4 Confidence Score Calculation**

Each alignment score includes a confidence level (Low/Medium/High) based
on data completeness:

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Confidence Level**    **Completeness Score**  **Meaning**
  ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
  High                    ≥75%                    Complete profile data,
                                                  high certainty

  Medium                  45-74%                  Partial data, moderate
                                                  certainty

  Low                     \<45%                   Limited data, verify in
                                                  interview
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

## 12. Alignment Score Algorithm

### 12.1 Overview

The Alignment Score (0-100%) measures candidate-job fit based on weighted, explainable factors. It is **not** a hire/no-hire recommendationâ€”it indicates relative alignment strength.

### 12.2 Component Weights

| Component | Weight | Description |
|-----------|--------|-------------|
| Hard Skills Match | 35% | Required skills from job description |
| Experience Relevance | 25% | Years + domain match |
| Industry Alignment | 15% | Same/adjacent industry experience |
| Seniority Fit | 15% | Title level appropriate for role |
| Location Match | 10% | Geography compatibility |

**Total: 100%**

### 12.3 Calculation Methodology

#### 12.3.1 Hard Skills Match (35%)

```python
def calculate_skills_match(required_skills: list, candidate_skills: list) -> float:
    """
    Uses ESCO taxonomy for skill normalization.
    Semantic similarity for non-exact matches.
    """
    exact_matches = len(set(required_skills) & set(candidate_skills))
    
    # Semantic matching for remaining skills
    semantic_matches = 0
    for req_skill in required_skills:
        if req_skill not in candidate_skills:
            best_similarity = max(
                cosine_similarity(embed(req_skill), embed(cand_skill))
                for cand_skill in candidate_skills
            )
            if best_similarity > 0.85:  # High similarity threshold
                semantic_matches += best_similarity
    
    total_match = (exact_matches + semantic_matches) / len(required_skills)
    return min(total_match, 1.0)  # Cap at 100%
```

#### 12.3.2 Experience Relevance (25%)

```python
def calculate_experience_score(
    required_years: int,
    candidate_years: int,
    domain_overlap: float  # 0-1 from job description analysis
) -> float:
    """
    Penalizes both under and over-qualification.
    """
    year_ratio = candidate_years / required_years
    
    if year_ratio < 0.7:
        year_score = year_ratio / 0.7 * 0.7  # Max 70% if under-qualified
    elif year_ratio <= 1.3:
        year_score = 1.0  # Sweet spot
    else:
        # Slight penalty for overqualification (flight risk)
        year_score = 1.0 - (year_ratio - 1.3) * 0.15
        year_score = max(year_score, 0.7)
    
    return (year_score * 0.6) + (domain_overlap * 0.4)
```

#### 12.3.3 Industry Alignment (15%)

```python
INDUSTRY_ADJACENCY = {
    "fintech": ["banking", "finance", "payments", "insurance"],
    "healthtech": ["healthcare", "pharma", "biotech", "medtech"],
    # ... full mapping
}

def calculate_industry_score(required_industry: str, candidate_industries: list) -> float:
    if required_industry in candidate_industries:
        return 1.0
    
    adjacent = INDUSTRY_ADJACENCY.get(required_industry, [])
    if any(ind in adjacent for ind in candidate_industries):
        return 0.75
    
    return 0.3  # Transferable skills baseline
```

#### 12.3.4 Seniority Fit (15%)

```python
SENIORITY_LEVELS = {
    "intern": 1, "junior": 2, "mid": 3, "senior": 4,
    "lead": 5, "principal": 6, "director": 7, "vp": 8, "c-level": 9
}

def calculate_seniority_score(required_level: str, candidate_level: str) -> float:
    req = SENIORITY_LEVELS.get(required_level, 3)
    cand = SENIORITY_LEVELS.get(candidate_level, 3)
    
    diff = cand - req
    
    if diff == 0:
        return 1.0
    elif diff == 1:
        return 0.85  # Slightly senior, may be ok
    elif diff == -1:
        return 0.75  # Stretch role
    elif diff > 1:
        return 0.6   # Overqualified risk
    else:
        return 0.5   # Under-qualified
```

#### 12.3.5 Location Match (10%)

```python
def calculate_location_score(
    job_location: str,
    job_remote_policy: str,  # "remote", "hybrid", "onsite"
    candidate_location: str,
    candidate_willing_to_relocate: bool
) -> float:
    if job_remote_policy == "remote":
        return 1.0
    
    same_city = normalize_city(job_location) == normalize_city(candidate_location)
    same_country = extract_country(job_location) == extract_country(candidate_location)
    
    if same_city:
        return 1.0
    elif same_country and job_remote_policy == "hybrid":
        return 0.85
    elif candidate_willing_to_relocate:
        return 0.7
    elif same_country:
        return 0.5
    else:
        return 0.3
```

### 12.4 Confidence Score Calculation

Each alignment score includes a confidence level (Low/Medium/High) based on data completeness:

```python
def calculate_confidence(profile_data: dict) -> str:
    completeness_factors = {
        "has_summary": 0.15,
        "has_3plus_experiences": 0.20,
        "has_skills_section": 0.20,
        "has_education": 0.10,
        "has_recommendations": 0.15,
        "profile_updated_90_days": 0.10,
        "has_certifications": 0.05,
        "has_public_posts": 0.05
    }
    
    score = sum(
        weight for factor, weight in completeness_factors.items()
        if profile_data.get(factor, False)
    )
    
    if score >= 0.75:
        return "High"
    elif score >= 0.45:
        return "Medium"
    else:
        return "Low"
```

## 17. Error Handling & Edge Cases

### 17.1 Data Retrieval Failures

| Scenario | User Message | System Action |
|----------|--------------|---------------|

| Profile is private | "This profile has privacy restrictions. Limited data available." | Partial charge (50%) |
| API rate limit | "High demand. Please retry in 5 minutes." | Auto-retry, no charge |
| API down | "Service temporarily unavailable. Your credits are safe." | Queue for later |

### 17.2 Scoring Edge Cases

| Scenario | Handling |
|----------|----------|
| No skills listed on profile | Score skills at 0%, flag confidence as "Low" |
| No experience listed | Cannot generate score, show error |
| Experience >20 years | Cap at 20 for calculation, show actual in profile |
| Multiple current roles | Use primary (longest tenure) for seniority |

AI-Powered Recruiting Software

Comprehensive Market Research & Feasibility Analysis

December 2024

**Prepared for Atlas Intelligence**

*Confidential Business Strategy Document*

Executive Summary

This document presents comprehensive market research for a four-tier AI
recruiting software concept designed for the Danish SMB market. The
analysis covers competitive landscape, technical feasibility, legal
compliance requirements, pricing validation, and strategic
recommendations.

Business Concept Overview

The proposed software offers a tiered approach to candidate sourcing and
evaluation:

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Tier**          **Price**      **Value Proposition**
  ----------------- -------------- ---------------------------------------
  Step 1: Job       **Free**       Job parsing, company context, team
  Intake                           analysis

  Step 2: Profile   €50/profile    Skills matching, experience alignment
  Matching                         scoring

  Step 3:           €150/profile   Personality assessment from LinkedIn
  Personality                      data
  Profiling                        

  Step 4: Outreach  €250/profile   Connection mapping, optimal outreach
  Strategy                         paths
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

**Target: €2,000 per hiring cycle** vs. €12,000-€20,000 traditional
agency fees (80-90% cost reduction).

Key Findings Summary

-   **Technical Feasibility: SOLVED** - Bright Data API provides all
    necessary LinkedIn data at €0.001-0.05/record

-   **Market Opportunity: STRONG** - 80-90% cost reduction vs. agencies,
    SMB market underserved

-   **Scientific Validity: MAJOR CONCERN** - Personality profiling lacks
    peer-reviewed validation

-   **Legal Compliance: CRITICAL BLOCKER** - Step 3 likely violates GDPR
    Article 22 and EU AI Act

Competitive Landscape Analysis

The AI recruiting software market is dominated by several major players,
each with distinct positioning and pricing strategies.

Major Competitors

  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Platform**     **Pricing**         **Database**        **Key Strength**
  ---------------- ------------------- ------------------- -------------------
  LinkedIn         Enterprise          950M+ profiles      Native data access
  Recruiter                                                

  SeekOut          \$499-1,999+/mo     330M profiles       Diversity hiring

  HireEZ           \$169-199/user/mo   800M+ across 30     Multi-source
                                       platforms           aggregation

  Findem           Undisclosed         1.6T data points    Attribute-based
                                                           search

  100Hires         \$399/mo unlimited  Live LinkedIn data  Transparent pricing
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Competitive Gaps Identified

-   Most tools focus on sourcing volume, not hiring decision quality

-   Personality profiling largely absent or superficial in existing
    solutions

-   Pricing models favor enterprise (per-user seats) - SMB market
    underserved

-   Pricing opacity standard (90%+ require sales calls)

Legal & Compliance Analysis

The proposed software faces significant regulatory requirements in the
EU, primarily from three frameworks: GDPR, the EU AI Act, and
LinkedIn\'s Terms of Service.

GDPR Article 22 - Automated Decision-Making

GDPR Article 22 prohibits decisions \'based solely on automated
processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects or
similarly significantly affects\' individuals. **Recruitment decisions
qualify as \'significantly affects\'.**

Compliance Requirements

-   **Transparency:** Must disclose AI involvement, explain logic,
    provide meaningful information about decision-making

-   **Human-in-the-loop:** Cannot be fully automated; meaningful human
    review required

-   **DPIA Required:** Data Protection Impact Assessment mandatory
    before implementation

-   **Special Category Data Risk:** Personality profiling may infer
    protected characteristics (ethnicity, religion, health)

EU AI Act - High-Risk Classification

The EU AI Act (Regulation 2024/1689), effective August 2024, explicitly
classifies AI used in recruitment as **HIGH-RISK** under Annex III.

High-Risk AI Systems in Recruitment (Annex III)

*(a)* AI systems intended to be used for the recruitment or selection of
natural persons, in particular to **place targeted job advertisements,
analyse and filter job applications, and evaluate candidates**

*(b)* AI systems intended to be used to make decisions affecting terms
of work-related relationships, **based on individual behaviour or
personal traits**

Implementation Timeline

-   **February 2025:** Prohibited AI practices and AI literacy
    obligations take effect

-   **August 2026:** High-risk system requirements fully applicable

-   **Worker notification:** Required before implementing high-risk AI
    in workplace

-   **Human oversight:** Must be established by individuals with
    appropriate competence and authority

LinkedIn Data Access - Legal Status

The hiQ Labs v. LinkedIn case established important precedents for data
scraping:

-   Ninth Circuit (2022): Scraping **publicly available** data does not
    violate Computer Fraud and Abuse Act

-   **However:** LinkedIn\'s User Agreement prohibits scraping -
    contract-based claims upheld

-   **Settlement (Dec 2022):** \$500,000 judgment against hiQ, permanent
    injunction

-   **Bright Data:** Won 2024 court cases against Meta and X -
    established legal precedent for compliant scraping

Risk Assessment by Tier

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Product Tier**   **Risk Level** **Assessment**
  ------------------ -------------- --------------------------------------
  Step 1: Job Intake **LOW**        No personal data processing; standard
                                    business intelligence

  Step 2: Profile    **MEDIUM**     Lower risk if presented as
  Matching                          \'suggestions\' not \'decisions\'

  Step 3:            **CRITICAL**   GDPR Article 22 violation likely; EU
  Personality                       AI Act high-risk; potential
  Profiling                         discrimination

  Step 4: Outreach   **MEDIUM**     Factual network analysis - not
  Strategy                          predictive profiling
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Personality Profiling Scientific Validity

Research into LinkedIn-based personality assessment tools reveals
significant concerns:

-   **2022 ACM Audit:** Crystal Knows and Humantic AI showed
    instability - resume format changes produced different personality
    predictions for same person

-   **Insufficient Text Volume:** Psycholinguistics requires large text
    samples; LinkedIn profiles often insufficient

-   **Authorship Issues:** Profile text may be written by others
    (professional writers, AI tools)

-   **No Independent Validation:** 80-97% accuracy claims unverified by
    peer-reviewed research

Market Opportunity: Denmark

Danish Labour Market Context

-   **Unemployment:** 2.5% (May 2024) - all-time low creating acute
    talent shortages

-   **Projected Shortfall:** 150,000+ skilled workers by 2035

-   **Employment Rate:** 76.6% (2023) - 6.2 percentage points above EU
    average

-   **GDP per capita:** €64,400 (2022) - 81.9% above EU average

-   **Foreign Labour:** 11%+ of total employment and growing

Recruitment Agency Fees

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Market**              **Fee Range**           **For €80K Position**
  ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
  Denmark                 15-25% of salary        €12,000 - €20,000

  Germany                 15-30% of salary        €12,000 - €24,000

  UK                      15-20% of salary        €12,000 - €16,000

  **Proposed Software**   **€2,000 flat**         **80-90% savings**
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Target Customer Profile

**Danish SMBs (50-500 employees) hiring 5-20 people/year**

-   Current spend: €60,000 - €400,000/year on agency fees

-   Potential savings: €50,000 - €180,000 annually with proposed
    software

-   Pain point: Can\'t afford €169-499/user/month enterprise tools

-   Decision maker: HR manager or founder (not procurement)

Strategic Recommendations

Immediate Actions (Pre-Launch)

1.  **Engage GDPR Lawyer:** Danish-based specialist for compliance
    review before any development

2.  **Restructure Step 3:** Replace \'personality profiling\' with
    legally defensible alternatives

3.  **Human-in-the-loop:** All scores presented as \'suggestions for
    human review\'

4.  **Transparency Layer:** Explain all scoring logic, allow candidates
    to contest/correct

Recommended Step 3 Alternatives

Replace \'personality profiling\' with factual, defensible analysis:

-   **Communication Style Indicators:** Post frequency, language
    formality (factual, not predictive)

-   **Career Trajectory Analysis:** Job progression, tenure patterns
    (factual historical data)

-   **Skills Complementarity Score:** Team skills gap analysis (factual
    comparison)

-   **Engagement Metrics:** LinkedIn activity levels, profile
    completeness

Phased Launch Strategy

Phase 1: Low-Risk MVP (2-4 weeks)

1.  **Step 1 (Free):** Job parsing, company/team context gathering

2.  **Step 2 (€50/profile):** Skills matching, experience alignment,
    factual scoring only

3.  **Step 4 (€250/profile):** Connection mapping, outreach path
    analysis

**Result:** €300 per candidate (vs. original €450), still 85% cheaper
than agencies

Phase 2: Post-Legal Validation

Reintroduce Step 3 as \'Career Insights Package\' (€150) with explicit
consent flows, DPIA compliance, and human review requirements. Include
disclaimer: \'Insights for human evaluation, not hiring
recommendations.\'

Competitive Positioning

-   **Transparency:** \'Honest AI that shows its work\' - full
    explainability

-   **SMB Focus:** \'Enterprise recruiting power at startup prices\'

-   **Ethics-First:** \'GDPR-first design, no black-box algorithms\'

-   **Pricing:** Transparent, published pricing (differentiate from 90%
    of competitors)

Conclusion

The AI recruiting software concept addresses a genuine market need with
compelling unit economics. The 80-90% cost reduction versus traditional
agencies is validated by extensive fee benchmarking across European
markets.

However, **Step 3 (Personality Profiling) presents unacceptable legal
risk in its current form**. Both GDPR Article 22 and the EU AI Act
classify automated personality assessment in recruitment as high-risk,
requiring extensive compliance measures that would fundamentally change
the product design.

**Recommendation:** Proceed with Phase 1 MVP (Steps 1, 2, 4 only) while
engaging legal counsel to explore compliant alternatives for personality
insights. The revised €300/candidate offering still delivers significant
value and positions the product for market entry within 2-4 weeks.

Next Steps

5.  Engage Danish GDPR specialist for formal compliance review

6.  Validate €300 price point with 10 Danish HR managers

7.  Design Bright Data API integration architecture

8.  Develop brand positioning strategy emphasizing transparency and
    compliance

9.  Create content marketing plan: \'The honest guide to AI recruiting\'

*Document prepared by Claude for Atlas Intelligence*

*Research conducted December 23, 2024*

name: How to use Claude
description: An example project that also doubles as a how-to guide for using Claude. Chat with it to learn more about how to get the most out of chatting with Claude!

docs.content:
# Claude prompting guide

## General tips for effective prompting

### 1. Be clear and specific
   - Clearly state your task or question at the beginning of your message.
   - Provide context and details to help Claude understand your needs.
   - Break complex tasks into smaller, manageable steps.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Help me with a presentation."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I need help creating a 10-slide presentation for our quarterly sales meeting. The presentation should cover our Q2 sales performance, top-selling products, and sales targets for Q3. Please provide an outline with key points for each slide."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt provides specific details about the task, including the number of slides, the purpose of the presentation, and the key topics to be covered.

### 2. Use examples
   - Provide examples of the kind of output you're looking for.
   - If you want a specific format or style, show Claude an example.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Write a professional email."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I need to write a professional email to a client about a project delay. Here's a similar email I've sent before:

   'Dear [Client],
   I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to update you on the progress of [Project Name]. Unfortunately, we've encountered an unexpected issue that will delay our completion date by approximately two weeks. We're working diligently to resolve this and will keep you updated on our progress.
   Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.
   Best regards,
   [Your Name]'

   Help me draft a new email following a similar tone and structure, but for our current situation where we're delayed by a month due to supply chain issues."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt provides a concrete example of the desired style and tone, giving Claude a clear reference point for the new email.

### 3. Encourage thinking
   - For complex tasks, ask Claude to "think step-by-step" or "explain your reasoning."
   - This can lead to more accurate and detailed responses.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "How can I improve team productivity?"
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I'm looking to improve my team's productivity. Think through this step-by-step, considering the following factors:
   1. Current productivity blockers (e.g., too many meetings, unclear priorities)
   2. Potential solutions (e.g., time management techniques, project management tools)
   3. Implementation challenges
   4. Methods to measure improvement

   For each step, please provide a brief explanation of your reasoning. Then summarize your ideas at the end."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt asks Claude to think through the problem systematically, providing a guided structure for the response and asking for explanations of the reasoning process. It also prompts Claude to create a summary at the end for easier reading.

### 4. Iterative refinement
   - If Claude's first response isn't quite right, ask for clarifications or modifications.
   - You can always say "That's close, but can you adjust X to be more like Y?"

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Make it better."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "That’s a good start, but please refine it further. Make the following adjustments:
   1. Make the tone more casual and friendly
   2. Add a specific example of how our product has helped a customer
   3. Shorten the second paragraph to focus more on the benefits rather than the features"
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt provides specific feedback and clear instructions for improvements, allowing Claude to make targeted adjustments instead of just relying on Claude’s innate sense of what “better” might be — which is likely different from the user’s definition!

### 5. Leverage Claude's knowledge
   - Claude has broad knowledge across many fields. Don't hesitate to ask for explanations or background information
   - Be sure to include relevant context and details so that Claude’s response is maximally targeted to be helpful

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "What is marketing? How do I do it?"
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I'm developing a marketing strategy for a new eco-friendly cleaning product line. Can you provide an overview of current trends in green marketing? Please include:
   1. Key messaging strategies that resonate with environmentally conscious consumers
   2. Effective channels for reaching this audience
   3. Examples of successful green marketing campaigns from the past year
   4. Potential pitfalls to avoid (e.g., greenwashing accusations)

   This information will help me shape our marketing approach."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt asks for specific, contextually relevant  information that leverages Claude's broad knowledge base. It provides context for how the information will be used, which helps Claude frame its answer in the most relevant way.

### 6. Use role-playing
   - Ask Claude to adopt a specific role or perspective when responding.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Help me prepare for a negotiation."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "You are a fabric supplier for my backpack manufacturing company. I'm preparing for a negotiation with this supplier to reduce prices by 10%. As the supplier, please provide:
   1. Three potential objections to our request for a price reduction
   2. For each objection, suggest a counterargument from my perspective
   3. Two alternative proposals the supplier might offer instead of a straight price cut

   Then, switch roles and provide advice on how I, as the buyer, can best approach this negotiation to achieve our goal."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt uses role-playing to explore multiple perspectives of the negotiation, providing a more comprehensive preparation. Role-playing also encourages Claude to more readily adopt the nuances of specific perspectives, increasing the intelligence and performance of Claude’s response.


## Task-specific tips and examples

### Content Creation

1. **Specify your audience**
   - Tell Claude who the content is for.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Write something about cybersecurity."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I need to write a blog post about cybersecurity best practices for small business owners. The audience is not very tech-savvy, so the content should be:
   1. Easy to understand, avoiding technical jargon where possible
   2. Practical, with actionable tips they can implement quickly
   3. Engaging and slightly humorous to keep their interest

   Please provide an outline for a 1000-word blog post that covers the top 5 cybersecurity practices these business owners should adopt."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: The good prompt specifies the audience, desired tone, and key characteristics of the content, giving Claude clear guidelines for creating appropriate and effective output.

2. **Define the tone and style**
   - Describe the desired tone.
   - If you have a style guide, mention key points from it.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Write a product description."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Please help me write a product description for our new ergonomic office chair. Use a professional but engaging tone. Our brand voice is friendly, innovative, and health-conscious. The description should:
   1. Highlight the chair's key ergonomic features
   2. Explain how these features benefit the user's health and productivity
   3. Include a brief mention of the sustainable materials used
   4. End with a call-to-action encouraging readers to try the chair

   Aim for about 200 words."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt provides clear guidance on the tone, style, and specific elements to include in the product description.

3. **Define output structure**
   - Provide a basic outline or list of points you want covered.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Create a presentation on our company results."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I need to create a presentation on our Q2 results. Structure this with the following sections:
   1. Overview
   2. Sales Performance
   3. Customer Acquisition
   4. Challenges
   5. Q3 Outlook

   For each section, suggest 3-4 key points to cover, based on typical business presentations. Also, recommend one type of data visualization (e.g., graph, chart) that would be effective for each section."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt provides a clear structure and asks for specific elements (key points and data visualizations) for each section.

### Document summary and Q&A

1. **Be specific about what you want**
   - Ask for a summary of specific aspects or sections of the document.
   - Frame your questions clearly and directly.
   - Be sure to specify what kind of summary (output structure, content type) you want

2. **Use the document names**
   - Refer to attached documents by name.

3. **Ask for citations**
   - Request that Claude cites specific parts of the document in its answers.

Here is an example that combines all three of the above techniques:

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Summarize this report for me."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I've attached a 50-page market research report called 'Tech Industry Trends 2023'. Can you provide a 2-paragraph summary focusing on AI and machine learning trends? Then, please answer these questions:
   1. What are the top 3 AI applications in business for this year?
   2. How is machine learning impacting job roles in the tech industry?
   3. What potential risks or challenges does the report mention regarding AI adoption?

   Please cite specific sections or page numbers when answering these questions."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt specifies the exact focus of the summary, provides specific questions, and asks for citations, ensuring a more targeted and useful response. It also indicates the ideal summary output structure, such as limiting the response to 2 paragraphs.

### Data analysis and visualization

1. **Specify the desired format**
   - Clearly describe the format you want the data in.

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Analyze our sales data."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "I've attached a spreadsheet called 'Sales Data 2023'. Can you analyze this data and present the key findings in the following format:

   1. Executive Summary (2-3 sentences)

   2. Key Metrics:
      - Total sales for each quarter
      - Top-performing product category
      - Highest growth region

   3. Trends:
      - List 3 notable trends, each with a brief explanation

   4. Recommendations:
      - Provide 3 data-driven recommendations, each with a brief rationale

   After the analysis, suggest three types of data visualizations that would effectively communicate these findings."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt provides a clear structure for the analysis, specifies key metrics to focus on, and asks for recommendations and visualization suggestions for further formatting.

### Brainstorming
 1. Use Claude to generate ideas by asking for a list of possibilities or alternatives.
     - Be specific about what topics you want Claude to cover in its brainstorming

   Bad prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Give me some team-building ideas."
   </prompt>

   Good prompt:
   <prompt>
   "We need to come up with team-building activities for our remote team of 20 people. Can you help me brainstorm by:
   1. Suggesting 10 virtual team-building activities that promote collaboration
   2. For each activity, briefly explain how it fosters teamwork
   3. Indicate which activities are best for:
      a) Ice-breakers
      b) Improving communication
      c) Problem-solving skills
   4. Suggest one low-cost option and one premium option."
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt provides specific parameters for the brainstorming session, including the number of ideas, type of activities, and additional categorization, resulting in a more structured and useful output.

2. Request responses in specific formats like bullet points, numbered lists, or tables for easier reading.

   Bad Prompt:
   <prompt>
   "Compare project management software options."
   </prompt>

   Good Prompt:
   <prompt>
   "We're considering three different project management software options: Asana, Trello, and Microsoft Project. Can you compare these in a table format using the following criteria:
   1. Key Features
   2. Ease of Use
   3. Scalability
   4. Pricing (include specific plans if possible)
   5. Integration capabilities
   6. Best suited for (e.g., small teams, enterprise, specific industries)"
   </prompt>

   Why it's better: This prompt requests a specific structure (table) for the comparison, provides clear criteria, making the information easy to understand and apply.
  
## Troubleshooting, minimizing hallucinations, and maximizing performance

1. **Allow Claude to acknowledge uncertainty**
   - Tell Claude that it should say it doesn’t know if it doesn’t know. Ex. “If you're unsure about something, it's okay to admit it. Just say you don’t know.”

2. **Break down complex tasks**
   - If a task seems too large and Claude is missing steps or not performing certain steps well, break it into smaller steps and work through them with Claude one message at a time.

3. **Include all contextual information for new requests**
   - Claude doesn't retain information from previous conversations, so include all necessary context in each new conversation.

## Example good vs. bad prompt examples

These are more examples that combine multiple prompting techniques to showcase the stark difference between ineffective and highly effective prompts.

### Example 1: Marketing strategy development

Bad prompt:
<prompt>
"Help me create a marketing strategy."
</prompt>

Good prompt:
<prompt>
"As a senior marketing consultant, I need your help developing a comprehensive marketing strategy for our new eco-friendly smartphone accessory line. Our target audience is environmentally conscious millennials and Gen Z consumers. Please provide a detailed strategy that includes:

1. Market Analysis:
   - Current trends in eco-friendly tech accessories
   - 2-3 key competitors and their strategies
   - Potential market size and growth projections

2. Target Audience Persona:
   - Detailed description of our ideal customer
   - Their pain points and how our products solve them

3. Marketing Mix:
   - Product: Key features to highlight
   - Price: Suggested pricing strategy with rationale
   - Place: Recommended distribution channels
   - Promotion: 
     a) 5 marketing channels to focus on, with pros and cons for each
     b) 3 creative campaign ideas for launch

4. Content Strategy:
   - 5 content themes that would resonate with our audience
   - Suggested content types (e.g., blog posts, videos, infographics)

5. KPIs and Measurement:
   - 5 key metrics to track
   - Suggested tools for measuring these metrics

Please present this information in a structured format with headings and bullet points. Where relevant, explain your reasoning or provide brief examples.

After outlining the strategy, please identify any potential challenges or risks we should be aware of, and suggest mitigation strategies for each."
</prompt>

Why it's better: This prompt combines multiple techniques including role assignment, specific task breakdown, structured output request, brainstorming (for campaign ideas and content themes), and asking for explanations. It provides clear guidelines while allowing room for Claude's analysis and creativity.

### Example 2: Financial report analysis

Bad prompt:
<prompt>
"Analyze this financial report."
</prompt>

Good prompt:
<prompt>
"I've attached our company's Q2 financial report titled 'Q2_2023_Financial_Report.pdf'. Act as a seasoned CFO and analyze this report and prepare a briefing for our board of directors. Please structure your analysis as follows:

1. Executive Summary (3-4 sentences highlighting key points)

2. Financial Performance Overview:
   a) Revenue: Compare to previous quarter and same quarter last year
   b) Profit margins: Gross and Net, with explanations for any significant changes
   c) Cash flow: Highlight any concerns or positive developments

3. Key Performance Indicators:
   - List our top 5 KPIs and their current status (Use a table format)
   - For each KPI, provide a brief explanation of its significance and any notable trends

4. Segment Analysis:
   - Break down performance by our three main business segments
   - Identify the best and worst performing segments, with potential reasons for their performance

5. Balance Sheet Review:
   - Highlight any significant changes in assets, liabilities, or equity
   - Calculate and interpret key ratios (e.g., current ratio, debt-to-equity)

6. Forward-Looking Statements:
   - Based on this data, provide 3 key predictions for Q3
   - Suggest 2-3 strategic moves we should consider to improve our financial position

7. Risk Assessment:
   - Identify 3 potential financial risks based on this report
   - Propose mitigation strategies for each risk

8. Peer Comparison:
   - Compare our performance to 2-3 key competitors (use publicly available data)
   - Highlight areas where we're outperforming and areas for improvement

Please use charts or tables where appropriate to visualize data. For any assumptions or interpretations you make, please clearly state them and provide your reasoning.

After completing the analysis, please generate 5 potential questions that board members might ask about this report, along with suggested responses.

Finally, summarize this entire analysis into a single paragraph that I can use as an opening statement in the board meeting."
</prompt>

Why it's better: This prompt combines role-playing (as CFO), structured output, specific data analysis requests, predictive analysis, risk assessment, comparative analysis, and even anticipates follow-up questions. It provides a clear framework while encouraging deep analysis and strategic thinking.

docs.filename: Ang. tilbud til samarbejde mellem FlexeCharge og SVC
docs.content:
Sven Arnarsson <sven.krebs88@gmail.com>
10. jan. 2024, 15.46
til Christophe

Hej Chris,

Håber du er kommet godt ind i det nye år - og stort tillykke med seed funding forresten!
Baseret på vores snak sidst, har jeg udviklet et tilbud, jeg synes afspejler jeres behov og vækstambitioner.

Jeg har delt det op i en startfase med opsætning og tracking, og efterfølgende en månedlig retainer.
Jeg har virkelig givet dig den bedste pris jeg kan på startpakken, da det er den der tager den absolut mest tid. Derfor har jeg også sat den til en varighed på to mdr.

Her er en detaljeret gennemgang af tilbuddet:

Første og anden måned (januar og februar): Opsætning og Tracking 
Denne fase er afgørende for at opbygge den nødvendige infrastruktur for en data-drevet tilgang.
Dataopsamling og -opsætning:
Opsætning af server-side tagging, en moderne løsning for at omgå begrænsninger som adblockere og browserbaserede restriktioner på tredjepartscookies.
Implementering af analytiske værktøjer som Google Analytics, Tag manager, LinkedIn Conversion Pixel evt. Facebook Pixel for at indsamle præcise data om brugeradfærd på jeres website.
Dette vil inkludere sporing af interaktioner som sidevisninger, formularindsendelser og klik på nøgleelementer. Samt evt. tracking ønsker fra jer.
Opsætning af cookie bar og overensstemmelse med GDPR.
Tydelige KPI'er defineres i samråd med jer for at sikre, at vi måler det, der betyder mest for FlexeCharge.
Konverteringssporing:
Definering af konverteringer som er relevante for jeres forretningsmål.
Sporing af interaktioner som nyhedsbrevstilmeldinger og formularindsendelser.
Implementering af LinkedIn Conversion Pixel evt. Facebook Pixel for at indsamle præcise data om brugeradfærd på jeres website. Dette vil inkludere sporing af interaktioner som sidevisninger, formularindsendelser og klik på nøgleelementer. Samt evt. tracking ønsker fra jer.
Udvikling af Dashboards:
Brugervenlige dashboards i Google Data Studio med realtids performance data.
Månedlige rapporter med en dybdegående analyse af de indsamlede data.
SEO Audit og On-page Optimering:
En grundig SEO-audit for at identificere forbedringsområder.
Implementering af on-page optimeringer baseret på auditresultaterne.
Opsætning af Google Ads og LinkedIn Ads:
Målrettede kampagner med fokus på FlexeCharge's kernebudskaber og brandværdier.
LinkedIn Thought Leader ads for at styrke jeres brand.
Samt optimering af målrettede kampagner på Google Ads og LinkedIn Ads, inklusive målgruppeanalyse og copywriting af headlines etc. Samt implementering af LI og GA conversion tracking. Remarketing cookies etc. Igangsættelse af LinkedIn Thought Leader ads.
Pris 20.000 Kr. 
Efterfølgende Månedlig Retainer (fra marts)

Efter opstarten er gennemført, foreslår jeg en mere strømlinet, månedlig retainer pakke, hvor jeg fortsætter med at yde support og ekspertise inden for følgende områder som 50/50 rådgivende og eksekverende. Evt. samarbejder jeg med jeres nye junior marketing medarbejder, hvis I synes det giver mening.

Catch-ups med team ang. strategier og planlægning af månedlige og kvartalsmål: 
Justere tilgange og planlægge fremadrettet.
Månedlige møder med fokus på dybdegående analyse og planlægning af langsigtede mål.
Google Ads og LinkedIn Ads Management: 
Jeg vil fortsætte med at styre og optimere jeres Google Ads og LinkedIn Ads kampagner for at forbedre ROI og tilpasse strategier baseret på performance data. Eksempel:
Avanceret segmentering og målgruppeanalyse for at nå de mest relevante brugere og maksimere ROI.
Ugentlig overvågning af kampagnepræstationer og hurtig justering baseret på dataanalyse.
Månedlig dybdegående performanceanalyse og rapportering for at evaluere effektiviteten af kampagner.
Løbende gennemgang og optimering af dashboards:
Månedlig tilpasning af dashboards for at afspejle de seneste trends og resultater.
Integration af nye datakilder for at give en mere holistisk udsigt over marketing performance.
SEO gennemgang og optimering:
Fortsat overvågning og løbende SEO-optimeringer for at sikre, at jeres website forbliver konkurrencedygtigt i søgemaskinerne.
Pris 10.000 Kr. 

Månedlig retainer kan op og ned justeres efter ønske, hvis der er brug for flere eller færre timer. 
I dette eksempel regner jeg med at bruge 6 timer på rådgivning og 6 timer på eksekvering. 

-----
Ring endelig hvis du mangler andet info eller afklaring.
Som nævnt synes jeg FlexeCharge er en fed case, og jeg er sikker på at vi sammen vil kunne få det endnu mere ud over rampen.
Og så vil jeg selvfølgelig glæde mig til at arbejde sammen med dig igen! :)
--

De bedste hilsener / Best regards
Sven Arnarsson
Owner & Marketing Consultant,
SVC ApS
+45 29128381

Christophe Christophe@flexecharge.com via flexechargecom.onmicrosoft.com
tirs. 16. jan., 21.07
til mig

Tak Sven, det lyder fornunfigt.
Vi skal dog lige tilpasse tilbudet lidt, da det er f. eks. ikke relevant med Facebook ads.

Hvad tid kan jeg fange dig på mobilen imorgen?

Best regards,
Christophe

Det vigtigste er at vi får styr på tracking efter jeres behov.

Sven Arnarsson <sven.krebs88@gmail.com>
søn. 3. sep. 2023, 21.03
til Kim

Hej Kim

Jeg håber I havde en god fest igår  - og stort tillykke med dagen og næsten sølvbryllup :)

Jeg har nu skabt mig et foreløbigt overblik over jeres konto og kampagner. Jeg vil mene at der er en række kritiske områder, der kræver opmærksomhed - især vedrørende søgeordsoptimering, opsætningen af en remarketing pixel og komplet genopsætning af konverterings tracking.
Her følger en gennemgang af hovedpunkterne, men hvis du har tid til et kald i løbet af ugen, så ville det være perfekt. Så kan vi gennemgå dataen lidt grundigere og diskutere detaljer. 

Remarketing pixel/cookie vil jeg gerne sætte op for jer med det samme, men jeg har brug for admin adgang til Google Tag Manager,
som nævnt tidligere så er det admin adgang jeg skal have for at kunne lave ændringer: 
Skærmbillede 2023-09-03 kl. 19.56.56.png


Nedenfor har du en detaljeret oversigt over jeres resultater fra august, efterfulgt af forbedringsforslag og en skitseret tidsplan for et fremtidigt samarbejde.

August måneds resultater for tech.dk:

- Total Spend: DKK 60,135.73.
- Total Clicks: 1,448.
- Average Cost Per Click (CPC): DKK 41.53.
- Total Impressions: 15,362.
- Click-Through Rate (CTR): 9.43%.
- Conversion Rate: 0.35%.
- Average Conversion Value: DKK 5.00.
- Total Conversion Value: DKK 12,027.15.

Denne data indikerer, at I har investeret over 60.000 kr. på blot 5 konverteringer i august. De mulige årsager kan være:
1. Forkert opsætning af analyseværktøjer, som giver et skævt billede af konverteringer.
2. En reel lav konverteringsrate, hvilket tyder på en betaling på 12.000 kr. pr. konvertering - en overraskende høj pris.

Baseret på den data, jeg har undersøgt, tyder det på en kombination af begge årsager - så jeg har identificeret hvad jeg mener er nogle udfordringer og mangler både i Google Ads og på jeres hjemmeside:
 
Hovedpunkter

- Konverteringstracking
Der er udfordringer med hvordan konverteringer spores og rapporteres i Google Ads. Det påpeger advarslen jeg har indsat nedenfor fra Google Ads for eksempel.
Det er generelt ikke en god ide at bruge penge på annoncering, hvis ikke tracking er ordentlig på plads, og det tyder det stærkt på her. Google Ads, Google Analytics og Google Tag Manager spiller ikke korrekt sammen. 
image.png
Skærmbillede 2023-09-03 kl. 20.01.26.png

- Remarketing
Det ser ud som om, at der mangler en remarketing cookie på hjemmesiden - et kritisk værktøj for gen engagement af besøgende.
Da I bruger betydelige summer på at få folk på siden, taber I derfor en kæmpe mulighed for at annoncere til de samme mennesker igen - og det er virkelig ærgerligt.
image.png

- Brugerdata 
Jeg vil anbefale en integration af værktøjet Mouseflow for at I kan få dybere indsigt i brugeradfærden på jeres side. Derudover anbefaler jeg, at vi optimerer Google Analytics til at spille bedre sammen med Ads og Tag Manager. Det kan godt lyde lidt forvirrende, men det betyder egentligt bare, at vi kan være mere sikre på, at de resultater vi får vist, også passer.

- Søgeordsoptimering 
Der er behov for at revidere og forbedre, hvordan søgeordene som f.eks "flowmåling" og "flowmåling i dieselolie" er håndteret i jeres kampagner.
Der findes forskellige måder at købe keywords på. Jeg vil ikke gå for meget i detaljer her, men bare sige, at i eksemplet du nævner, så er "match metoden" lavet forkert, og der er en række søgeord, som kan optimeres ved at ændre på "match" metoden.

Eksempel:
Modified broad match (modificeret bredt match):
Med denne type kan du fastsætte specifikke ord, der skal være inkluderet i en søgning for at din annonce bliver vist.
Ved at bruge keywordet "+flowmåling +dieselolie", sikrer du, at begge ordene "flowmåling" og "dieselolie" skal være til stede i søgningen, men ikke nødvendigvis i den rækkefølge.


Næste skridt & tilbud:

Opstartspakke i oktober måned - 20.000 kr. - kun første måned pga. ekstra timer (50% rabat, hvis ikke resultaterne nås, som nævnt til sidst i mailen):
- Uge 1: Opsætning af remarketing cookie (hurtigst muligt) og komplet tidskrævende dybdegående analyse af Google Ads kontoen.
- Uge 2 & 3: Opstart og færdiggørelse af konverterings tracking og søgeordsoptimering samt SEO gennemgang af hjemmesiden.
- Uge 4: Gennemgang sammen med Tech.dk teamet af forbedringer, månedens performance og brugerdata. Samt oprettelse af Performance dashboards for Google Ads og Google Analytics

Vedligeholdelsespakke (fra november) - 10.000 kr./måned:
- Uge 1: Månedlig rapportering og opstart af annonce- &  søgeordsoptimering baseret på data fra foregående måned.
- Uge 2: Færdiggørelse af optimering og opsætning af remarketing-kampagne.
- Uge 3 & 4: Fortsat overvågning, opdatering af performance dashboards og support efter behov.

Hver måned en detaljeret rapport over MOM (month over month), performance og evt. kald med teamet, hvis der er behov for det. 

Jeg mener der er så stort et potentiale for forbedring, at hvis I ikke som minimum ser en 25% forbedring i konverteringer inden for tre måneder, tilbyder jeg en rabat på 50% på opstartspakken. Dette betyder, at I kun vil skulle betale 10.000 kr., og at I naturligvis har fuld frihed til at vælge, om I ønsker at fortsætte samarbejdet. 
Opsigelsesperioden på vedligeholdelsespakken er kun indeværende måned, så ønsker I ikke at fortsætte aftalen, kan den stoppes ved udgangen af den givne måned.
Men jeg vil være til rådighed for support og rådgivning, og opstår der problemer, så klarer vi det naturligvis hurtigst muligt. 

Jeg ser frem til at høre fra dig, forhåbentligt til et kald i løbet af den kommende uge.  
God aften
--

De bedste hilsener / Best regards
Sven Arnarsson
Owner & Marketing Specialist,
SV Consult ApS
+45 29128381

Kim Andersen <kim@tech.dk>
man. 4. sep. 2023, 14.30
til Mikkel, mig

Hej Sven,

 

Æv også at der var en del, men også meget godt.

Umiddelbart læser jeg det som følgende:

 

Opsætning af de måder man kan se og tracke på er ikke god nok, det skal laves om.
Der er brugt 60 kkr, som faktisk er en del mere end jeg var klar over, og konverteringen er lav.
Der er lavet nogle helt faktuelle fejl, det omkring flow, måden keyword er sat op. Sikkert også på andre ord en flow
Du kan rende alt igennem, og den første måned vil være noget dyrere, men så kommer der styr på alt. Udover det tilbyder du også en vedligeholdelses aftale. Som jeg forstår det, så skal jeg opsige de andre, og så kan du tage over. I den forbindelse vil du så kunne sikre dig at de ikke har adgang til noget som helst?
Du nævner SEO indimellem, er det også en del af vedligehold?
 

De har lige skrevet til mig idag at de mener budget skal hæves.

 

Kim

Hej Kim

 

Jeg håber I havde en god fest igår  - og stort tillykke med dagen og næsten sølvbryllup :)

 

Jeg har nu skabt mig et foreløbigt overblik over jeres konto og kampagner. Jeg vil mene at der er en række kritiske områder, der kræver opmærksomhed - især vedrørende søgeordsoptimering, opsætningen af en remarketing pixel og komplet genopsætning af konverterings tracking.
Her følger en gennemgang af hovedpunkterne, men hvis du har tid til et kald i løbet af ugen, så ville det være perfekt. Så kan vi gennemgå dataen lidt grundigere og diskutere detaljer. 


Remarketing pixel/cookie vil jeg gerne sætte op for jer med det samme, men jeg har brug for admin adgang til Google Tag Manager,
som nævnt tidligere så er det admin adgang jeg skal have for at kunne lave ændringer: 




Nedenfor har du en detaljeret oversigt over jeres resultater fra august, efterfulgt af forbedringsforslag og en skitseret tidsplan for et fremtidigt samarbejde.

August måneds resultater for tech.dk:

- Total Spend: DKK 60,135.73.
- Total Clicks: 1,448.
